helm-toolkit/templates/manifests/_job-ks.message: why would this default to a boolean?

This defaults to a boolean because I didn't want to default it to 0.  0 is a valid value (means its disabled) and this function would insert "activeDeadlineSeconds: 0" into the chart's values, when it doesn't need to be there at all. So the user should pass "false" if they don't want to see the value at all, or specifies a specific value if they want to override.  My goal was to avoid changing the rendering of existing charts that use this function, if possible.

After thinking about it some more and doing some more testing, I removed the boolean false values as defaults, since gotpl will evaluate {{- if $backoffLimit }} to false if the parameter is not provided.  In the case of activeDeadlineSeconds, if the argument is not provided, or is provided with a value of 0, then {{- if $activeDeadlineSeconds }} evaluates to false, which is ok too.
one is an integer and another is a boolean?
See explanation to your comment on line 30.

can we not directly check the content of the file instead of just generically checking the count?

Well, at this point, the file is a zipped tar file. I check the content later after it's unzipped/untarred. Here, I'm exercising the "list_archives local" command to be sure it's returning the correct output, which should be one file at this point.
can we not extract and compare the database name created instead of doing a count match, also why do we need these seds for comparison?

Here I am exercising/testing the "list_databases local" command, to be sure that it returns one database. There are multiple output lines, so these seds remove the output lines before the line starting with "===", and then the "===" line itself, so that the only remaining lines are the lines containing database names.  Then I count those to be sure there are 1.  Next step is to verify database restoration, which verifies the content of the database archive.

These two parameters should be taken from Tobiko topology APIs because differs from node to node. I am not interested on using this feature of podman because we can use Tobiko's SSH tuneling, reducing all configuration effort to one single place that is very powerful and it is used for all other clients (example Docker, HTTP, etc.)

).connect()

The command I suppose would be used from tobiko test cases node, therefore it should support at least the name of the openstack node to connect to (local host by default). The command would use tobiko openstack topology APIs [1] to get ssh_client for given node name.

 from tobiko.openstack import topology

 node.podman_client.ping()

 this-command [--node nodename] command

isinstance(action_result, (dict, list))

nit: Instead of providing roles through nova, nova is consuming the default roles provided by keystone (admin, member, and reader).

The idea of using something common from keystone reduces the likelihood of similar, but different, roles implemented across projects (e.g., a role called observer versus reader versus auditor). This makes it easier to understand who can do what across projects, reduces divergence, and increases interoperability.

The scope denotes which type of token scope the policy needs to evaluate to True or False.

If you have an API that exposes system-level resources (or resources that might violate tenancy if end-users were to access them), like compute-hypervisors, then you might consider protecting that API with a policy that has scope_types = 'system'. Continuing with the example, this prevents project administrators from accessing the compute hypervisor API since their tokens are scoped to projects, not the system.

zaqar/common/policies/queues.py.message: We should make sure this is singular (e.g., queue instead of queues).

Interesting. I didn't think of putting everything in a single dictionary. 

When I've deprecated keystone policies I usually do the following:

  deprecated_get_all = policy.DeprecatedRule(
      name=LEGACY_QUEUES % 'create',
      check_str=base.UNPROTECTED
  )

But either way works fine I think.

This should be list, so

  messaging:queue:list

We should be able to use oslo_log here, which has constants available for each release. Here is an example I just wrote for keystone if it helps.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/594547/17/keystone/common/policies/credential.py@70

We could add a little more detail here, like:

  Policy queues:get_all is being deprecated in favor of 
  messaging:queue:list as an established convention
  for naming policies consistently. If you override
  policies in your deployment, please make sure you
  are using this updated policy name for your override. If
  not, this change is being applied automatically as the new
  default policy. The legacy policy name will be removed in 
  the T release.

That way operators have a good idea of what they need to do and why they need to do it.

I wonder if this would be a good fit for using a subresource?

  messaging:queue:stats:get

openstackclient/network/v2/floating_ip.p.message: Do we not need to return at least a 2-tuple here?  It's been long enough I don't recall what cliff will do...will check...

So the desire is that if you request something that is undefined because of an operator choice you get a null return set back instead of an error.  For example, in a TripleO deployment there is no such thing as floating IPs on the undercloud.  If you do an `openstack flosting ip list` you get "NotFoundException: NotFoundException: Unknown error" which is misleading.  I would rather there be no error at all and a return code of 0, indicating the null set.

It looks like this is only called in https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/branch/master/openstackclient/network/common.py

It is called in a few places. Some just make the call with no checking of the results, but a couple of the calls from take_action return up the results of the call.

It looks like when that bubbles up to cliff, there could be a problem with this here:

https://opendev.org/openstack/cliff/src/branch/master/cliff/display.py#L117

So probably should have this return some sane failure result.

tacker/vnflcm/vnflcm_driver.py.message: IMO, termination_timeout> 0 is guaranteed, so I think it's not necessary.

As per ETSI GS NFV-SOL 003 V2.6.1 (2019-04), Table 5.5.2.8-1:, gracefulTerminationTimeout is not a mandatory parameter even if terminationType is GRACEFUL.

Hence, this check is necessary.

This is not good practise - better would be to move the defaults to a vars file for centos-8, but another alternative is to do this:

- name: Include OS specific variables

Done
This should be 'lookup'?

Well now, I see that this is not supported with include_vars:

"msg": "{{ lookup('first_found', params, errors is not a valid option in include_vars"

This works, but only if there is a file:

  include_vars: "{{ lookup('first_found', params) }}"
  vars:
    params:
      files:
        - "{{ ansible_distribution | lower }}-{{ ansible_distribution_major_version }}.yaml"
      paths:
        - 'vars'

There are three choices here:

1. Move the defaults (for CentOS-8) into a vars file. (yay!)
2. Add 'failed_when: false' to the task. (yuk)
3. Add a conditional that only executes this task if "{{ ansible_distribution | lower }}-{{ ansible_distribution_major_version }} != 'centos-8'" (meh)

This could be more succinctly expressed as:

        dib_node_dist: "{{ (ansible_distribution == 'RedHat') ternary('rhel', 'centos') }}"

nit: double-space

What is purpose to load "first_found" if you have only one option "centos-7" in condition? Why only for centos7?

first_found checks for a list of files and path and return full path to the first combination found. https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/plugins/lookup/first_found.html  Right now this role supports for c8 as defulat and c7 in vars . To run this task only for c7, we added this condition.

yeah, so you don't need "first_found" with these conditions, just:

include_vars: centos-7.yaml
when:
    - ansible_distribution == "CentOS"
    - ansible_distribution_major_version == '7'

"first_found" is used when you you have a few files with variables and it doesn't need any conditions of "ansible_distribution", the whole point of using "first_found" is to avoid any conditions and let it automatically pick up the appropriate configuration.
Anyway, with one file it doesn't make sense to use it at all.
why block? it's only one task

I see, thank you.

So the cases being tested in this command are:
1 args - lists authinfo for specified arg
0 args - list all authinfos found, or "no user credentials" if no authinfoes

but in the case of user listing 2 or more args the code defaults to listing all authinfos.  I'd suggest either:
1. Setting Max args to 1 (see [0] for details) so that you can either get all authinfos known, or a single specified authinfo

or 2. adding another block of code to loop through the args and get authinfo for each specified arg.

[0] https://github.com/spf13/cobra#positional-and-custom-arguments

Thanks for suggestions.

Added MaxNargs(1) for get-credentials. 

    * To get all credentials, user will provide no args as it is now
    * To get a specific user credential, user will have mention the account name in args

The key is not everything IS redfish based a number of the methods are functionally duplicate behavior, so there is a fine line we need to walk, and we need to be willing to kind of take an intermediate path which is kind of how I viewed the patch to begin with.

Done.

I think it would be best with this patch to pave the path for the vendors to rebase their vmedia implementation (as well as other redfishy things) on top of our base/standard Redfish code.

The monster function way might not be the best possible approach considering the open-ended nature of those vendor-specific features.

The pattern you use to find lock files limits the search to "-delete_volume" locks. This is a worthy subset, but certainly doesn't cover *all* cinder locks. I think this could be clarified somewhere, perhaps in the commit message. This patch is a partial fix.
But it is configurable, via the 'lifetime' parameter. Perhaps you mean you don't plan to expose it at a higher level, e.g. as a tripleo parameter?

manifests/cron/fastener_purge.pp.message:
Several comments here:

1) What if system time has not been acquired (i.e. current time is near the UNIX epoch)?

2) Consider "-delete" instead of "-exec rm {}" (no need for a subprocess)

3) Because the locks are all in the root of cinder's service directory, the query could use mindepth/maxdepth to prevent descending into subdirectories (for safety)

The maxdepth (and mindepth) options aren't intuitive, and I think a maxdepth value of 0 means the command won't even step into /var/lib/cinder. I did some experiments and think you want "-maxdepth 1" (you should confirm).
I think you're right, Alan - I'm currently deploying the patchset on my lab in order to do some tests.
Also, can't we just assume that find is available by default on all distributions that we are testing, or is this false for some distro?
